Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Prucalopride for Postoperative Ileus in Elective Colorectal Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: multicentre, double-blind, parallel, placebo-controlled randomised trial

Participants.evidence: Eligible patients were adults undergoing elective colorectal resection, excluding those with inflammatory bowel disease or planned ileostomy.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to receive 2 mg prucalopride or placebo, administered 2 hours before surgery and daily for up to 6 days postoperatively.

Objective.evidence: This study assessed the effect of prucalopride, a selective serotonin-4-receptor agonist, on gut motility.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was time to GI-2, defined as passage of stool and tolerance of diet.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment by an external pharmacy.

Blinding.evidence: All participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 148 patients were randomised, 74 per group

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was no significant difference in median time to GI-2 between prucalopride and placebo groups: 3.5 versus 4 days (P = 0.124).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups, with no significant differences in complications or readmission rates.
